answers: cells [prompt on tissue sections; accept any specific cell types]
two-photon excitation microscopy/imaging [prompt on answers mentioning photons; do NOT accept one-photon microscopy
parts: Name these biological objects that are commonly imaged by conjugating them to fluorescent proteins. Time-lapse microscopy is alternatively named for viewing these basic units of biology “live”.

Recent improvements on live cell imaging include this technique that allows living tissues to be imaged up to 1 millimeter in depth. This technique is named for requiring a certain number of excitations from namesake particles before the signal is passed to a photomultiplier tube.

Another modern live-cell imaging technique makes use of labelled biomarkers conjugated to these tiny semiconductor particles for targeted imaging. These materials are most commonly made of cadmium selenide.

answers: Juno [do NOT accept or prompt on "Hera"]
parts: Name this element of divine essence possessed by every individual male in the Roman religious tradition, which served as a sort of guardian angel.

Women were generally believed to not possess genius, and instead were attended by the spirit of this goddess. This queen of the Roman pantheon was depicted on the day of her wedding to Jupiter in a statue at Samos.
In ancient art, the genius was sometimes depicted flanked by two of these household deities, who were tutelary deities of the hearth. These deities are often contrasted with penates.
Name this practice, common in hip-hop music, of taking a part of one song and using it in another song. Legally, this practice requires permission from the copyright holder.
In a precursor to sampling, a deejay would “voice” over a prerecorded riddim in dancehall music from this country. The most famous singer from this country recorded the track “Three Little Birds.”

The practice of unlicensed sampling declined after the Turtles sued this hip-hop group because Prince Paul sampled one of their songs without permission for an interlude on the album 3 Feet High and Rising.
Name this 2009 collection of lyric poetry by Maggie Nelson. It opens with the line “Suppose I were to begin by saying that I had fallen in love with a color.”

In Bluets, Nelson quotes many lines written by this man, such as “I grieve that grief can teach me nothing” from his essay “Experience.” This Transcendentalist wrote “Self-Reliance” and was friends with Henry David Thoreau.

Nelson writes “And please don’t talk to me about ‘things as they are’ being changed upon any ‘blue guitar,’” a reference to the poem “The Man with the Blue Guitar.” That poem, along with “The Idea of Order at Key West,” was originally published in this collection.

answers: Bronsted-Lowry acid-base classification [accept BL; prompt on Bronsted or Lowry definition alone]
parts: Name this reaction that uses acid catalysis to react a substituted phenyl-hydrazine with a carbonyl compound and generate an enamine intermediate that rearranges into an imine before being converted to the final product.
Most successful versions of the Fischer indole synthesis make use of a strong acid under this acid-base classification. In this classification, conjugate acids and bases form through proton exchange.
Fischer also names a reaction that produces one of these compounds by refluxing a carboxylic acid in the presence of an alcohol and a strong acid.

answers: Ida B. Wells [or Ida Bell Wells-Barnett]
parts: Name this practice, which George Tindall termed the “20th century auto-da-fe”. The first woman senator, Rebecca Felton, praised this practice in the case of Sam Hose.
This anti-lynching advocate was inspired by a lynching at the People’s Grocery in Memphis to write The Red Record.
This 14-year old boy was violently murdered in Mississippi in 1955, sparking outrage across the nation. This boy’s mother gave him an open casket at his funeral to show the horrors of racism.

answers: Kaplan [accept David Kaplan or Benjamin Kaplan]
Ludwig Wittgenstein [accept Wittgenstein on Rules and Private Language]
parts: Give this surname of that thinker, David, who invented the operator “DTHAT” for his analysis of indexicals and rigid designators. A second thinker with this surname, Benjamin, was a prominent copyright scholar at Columbia.

The original concept of the rigid designator was created by this Princeton philosopher and author of Naming and Necessity as a way of categorizing descriptions that have the same referent in all possible worlds.

Kripke himself created the nonsensical mathematical operation “quus” to illustrate his own ideas about this Austrian philosopher’s “Rules and Private Language”. Those ideas appear in his work Philosophical Investigations.

answers: limnic eruption [prompt on lake eruptions; prompt on lake overturn]
parts: Name these sometimes catastrophic events, when large clouds of gas called mazuku are released from lakes, suffocating people and wildlife.
The only directly observed examples of limnic eruptions have occured in this country, which is home to Lake Monoun. This central African country's largest port is Douala and its capital is Yaounde.

In 1986, this Cameroon volcanic crater lake experienced a limnic eruption that killed over 1,700 people. Along with Lake Monoun, this lake is the only place where a limnic eruption has been directly observed.

answers: V.S. Naipaul [or Sir Vidiadhar Surajprasad Naipaul]
parts: Name this character who meets his eventual wife Shama while painting signs for the Tulsi family.
This Trinidadian author wrote A House for Mr. Biswas.

After Mr. Biswas steals some of this food item, Jairam forces him to eat the rest until he develops stomach trouble. Miguel Ángel Asturias took almost twenty years to write a trilogy named for this food.
Name this 1620 battle where Count Tilly defeated the forces of Frederick the Winter King. After this battle, 27 prisoners were executed in Old Town Square.
The Battle of White Mountain was the first major battle of this war, which began with two defenestrations in Prague by Protestant rebels.
Count Tilly’s forces brutally sacked this city in 1631, burning it to the ground and killing 20,000 of its inhabitants. This city’s name became a byword for destruction.

answers: Emmy Noether [accept Noether’s 1st theorem or Noether’s 2nd theorem]
parts: Name this quantity whose SI unit is the joule-second. This quantity can be calculated as the time integral of the Lagrangian.

This German scientist and mathematician’s second theorem allows the symmetries of an action function to be characterized by differential equations. Her first theorem states that a physical system with continuous symmetries will have a corresponding conservation law.

In the path integral formalism, this function, which specifies the probability amplitude for a particle traveling across space in a given period of time, is equal to the exponential of i over h-bar times the action.
Name this poem delivered from the perspective of a corpse who hears “great guns”  that “shook all our coffins as we lay.”
In this other poem written by the author of “Channel Firing,” the speaker leans on a “coppice gate” and notices the title “frail, gaunt, and small” bird.
“Channel Firing” and “The Darkling Thrush” are both poems written by this author of Far from the Madding Crowd and Tess of the D’Urbervilles.

answers: Kenya (All three artists are from Nairobi)
Democratic Republic of the Congo [or DRC; prompt on Congo or Congolese]
parts: Name this home nation of Wangechi Mutu. The subject of the 2020 MoMA exhibition Projects 110, Michael Armitage, and the creator of the Sitting Allowance series, Peterson Kamwathi, are both from this country.

In 2018, the MoMA hosted its first solo exhibition of a black African artist, Bodys Isek Kingelez, who is a sculptor from this other African nation. In 1974, several elaborate palaces and pavilions were built in this nation for a World’s Fair-esque event that accompanied its hosting of the “Rumble in the Jungle”.

The discovery of elongated, central African examples of these articles of clothing were one of the earliest influences of African art on the European art scene, some of which in a museum apocryphally inspired Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d’Avignon.

answers: Yemen [or Republic of Yemen; accept Yaman]
Saudi Arabia [or Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]
parts: Name this incident, in which Jemaah Islamiyah killed over 200 people. An audio cassette tape with Osama bin Laden’s voice on it justified this incident in reference to the war on terror, saying “you will be killed just as you kill”.
al-Qaeda also backed an attack in this country on the USS Cole. Ali Abdullah Saleh served as this country’s first president after its “North” and “South” counterparts were unified into one country.

Osama bin Laden was closely related to this country’s royal family, from which his family’s oil wealth derives. This country’s ruler has the title “Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques” in reference to Mecca and Medina.

answers: In Praise of Shadows [or In'ei Raisan]
parts: Name this essay, which in a later section describes the beauty of a type of gold flecked lacquerware bowl and extensively contrasts the Western love of light and shining with a certain East Asian country's aesthetic of the title concept.

In Praise of Shadows was written by a novelist and critic from this country. Another critic from this country described the influence of the tea ceremony on this country's aesthetics in The Book of Tea.

Okakura, the author of The Book of Tea, may have inspired this philosopher's concept of "being there," or dasein. This philosopher argued that art is not merely an expression of a culture, but also a form of creation in his essay "The Origin of the Work of Art."

answers: planarian(s) [prompt on platyhelminthes; accept specific planarians like D. japonica]
being in grown in space [accept aboard/on the ISS or in (low earth) orbit; prompt on zero gravity, low gravity or microgravity with “in what type of environment does this condition occur?”]
parts: Name these triclad flatworms. These organisms were so popular in regenerative biology at the turn of the 20th century that a majority of Morgan’s own publications centered on them prior to his switch to fruit flies.

A far more recent study of the planarian D. japonica in 2017 found that fragments were capable of growing back into full worms even when placed in this specific type of extreme environment. Plant seedlings grown in this type of environment notably do not exhibit gravitropism.
Most modern planarian research back on Earth makes use of the worms to study this general process, also known as cellular senescence. Progeria is a condition that accelerates this process in humans.

answers: Renaissance [or The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy]
metahistory [or Metahistory: The Historical Imagination in Nineteenth-Century Europe]
parts: Name this empire. Edward Gibbon’s magnum opus is a six-volume History of the Decline and Fall of this empire.
While Gibbon trashed religion, Jacob Burckhardt was a student of theology, influencing his history of this era’s “civilization”.

Hayden White claims that historians determine the narrative of a history in a book titled for this concept. White divides historians and philosophers into categories based on “emplotment” in his theory of this concept.
Name this theatrical character who stages plays using the inmates of Charenton asylum.
The use of music and the distancing effect are ways that Peter Weiss’ play Marat/Sade was influenced by a form of theatre described by this adjective. It was promoted by Bertolt Brecht.
Throughout the play, the Marquis de Sade speaks to the audience, which is often referred to as “breaking” this construct.

answers: Butterfly Lovers Violin Concerto [accept liáng zhù xiǎo tí qín xié zòu qǔ]
parts: Francois Schubert wrote a violin showpiece titled for this insect. A more famous work from Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov’s opera The Tale of Tsar Saltan depicts the “flight” of this insect.
Threnody I: The Night of the Electronic Insects is the first of “thirteen images from the dark land” that comprise this American composer’s electric string quartet Black Angels.
The rising notes “B-D-E-G” begin the solo part of this violin concerto. Along with the Yellow River Piano Concerto, this is one of the most famous Chinese concertos.

answers: nudge theory [accept word forms like nudging]
parts: Name this theory, which posits that governments should use behavioral economics and psychological priming to subtly cause people to behave in more socially optimal ways.

The objective of nudging is to alter the architecture of these things in a way that makes "good" decisions more likely. These things are faced by people who suffer "analysis paralysis," which results from there being several options.
Nudging is contrasted with rational choice theory in this Daniel Kahneman book. This book describes "System 1" and "System 2," which refer to intuitive and deliberate modes of the title action.
